channel.title: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO
channel.description: Hello, I was wondering if a bank of toggle switches could be wired passively with resistors to one gpio? If the AD converter is 12 bit then 12 switches right? With proper scaling each unique switch state could be utilized.

item.title: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO
item.dc:creator: @TTotelka
item.description:
@TTotelka wrote:

Great, thanks a lot, that's what I needed to know!

Read full topic
item.source: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO

item.title: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO
item.dc:creator: @Gavin Gavin
item.description:
@Gavin wrote:

Keep the resistor values the same as described, doesn't mater how many steps you have or even if you add extra steps later, just keep the resister value the same.
I had this setup with 20 momentary switches and all worked fine.
2 things to note if you are using momentary / toggle switches that are all connected to one analogue input..
1 - You can only press one switch at a time.
2 - There will be tiny fractional delay as the signal rises to its analogue value.

Read full topic

item.title: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO
item.dc:creator: @johannes johannes
item.description:
@johannes wrote:

johannes:

Use a topology like this to convert to an integer:adjust the "math/*c" parameter to the number of steps of your switch.

Sorry, correction...: adjust the "math/*c" parameter to the number of steps of your switch minus 1. So 8 position switch -> "math/*c" with value 7.

Read full topic

item.source: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO

item.title: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO
item.dc:creator: @johannes johannes
item.description:
@johannes wrote:

kashis:

and then he wiggles very fast in th 30's, sometimes high in the 20's and begin 40's

I suspect that comes from an open input.

Your readings match for a 7-position switch and corresponding 6-resistor string, but you seem to have an 8-or-more position switch? A capacitor is not the right solution here, you need to correct your resistor/switch circuit.

Read full topic

item.title: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO
item.dc:creator: @johannes johannes
item.description:
@johannes wrote:

kashis:

skipping one step

Most likely the "math/*c" parameter is off by one. Use a "disp/dial p" after "math/*c" to diagnose, it should show almost round numbers.

Read full topic

item.source: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO

item.title: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO
item.dc:creator: @johannes johannes
item.description:
@johannes wrote:

On the switch, the pin I marked with the blue "X" is the "common", that needs to go to the analog gpio input, and not connect to anything else.
(if I can see it correctly from your picture, luckily your rotary switch does not cover its internals)

If your red wire is VDDA, and black wire GND, then your switch will shortcircuit VDDA to GND in that position.
I think you need to remove the resistor between the common and the previous terminal, and connect the red wire to that terminal.

Read full topic
item.source: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO

item.title: Multiple toggle switches on one GPIO
item.dc:creator: @kashis dennis
item.description:
@kashis wrote:

hi johannes, thanks for the fast reply.
I hope you can see the connections good at the picture:

IMG_20160731_171834.jpg2336x4160 1.88 MB

i made on both sides a cable out for testing ,so i can put both on gnd and vdda for testing. Not one side worked. It doesnt matter or i connect the white or red to the gnd or vdda,it both shuts down

before i started from the other side (from the righ screw up ,at the picture)and went counter clockwise counting till 8.here i didnt took any reading or any disconnection. The switch was working because i tested the voltage and this went from 3v in steps to 0.3 if i remember correct the exact voltages.
After checking some ways i thought what could help ,i saw it disconnected if i had the vdda cable to the point where i started now(the point in the picture with the green cable attached).
So i thought that must be the ground and i connected the white cable to the other end with the cable to the axo PA7. No reading only disconnected at the specific point in the picture.

axo patch.png1265x747 126 KB

IMG_20160731_174736.jpg2336x4160 2.41 MB

i checked the help gpio-in like you told me before wih other problem and also no reading
On a sidenote..i have now all 10k pots and i see no leaking as before!so the sound will be more steady.
DIAL MATRIX SYNTH FOR PANEL2.axp (118.4 KB)

i added some pictures and the patch,i hope this give a it more clearity

Read full topic
